Description: INFORMATION REQUIRED FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF RAILS, SNIPES, COOTS, AND GALLINULES IS COLLECTED ANNUALLY THROUGHOUT THE DEVELOPED, SOUTHERN PORTION OF ONTARIO, CANADA. BY CONTRAST, COLLECTION OF THESE IMPORTANT DATA IS ENTIRELY LACKING FOR THESE SPECIES IN THE LESS-DEVELOPED CENTRAL AND NORTHERN PORTIONS OF ONTARIO DUE TO LOGISTICAL CHALLENGES. THIS PROJECT FILLS THIS KNOWLEDGE GAP BY IMPLEMENTING THE ONTARIO BREEDING BIRD ATLAS MARSHBIRD SURVEY, A COLLABORATIVE 5-YEAR PROJECT (20212025) CO-DELIVERED BY BIRDS CANADA, WHICH WILL COMPLETE THE REQUIRED SURVEYS THROUGHOUT ONTARIO. THE INFORMATION COLLECTED BY THE PROJECT WILL BE IMMEDIATELY USEFUL FOR A VARIETY OF CONSERVATION INITIATIVES, INCLUDING SPECIES-AT-RISK STATUS ASSESSMENTS BY THE COMMITTEE ON THE STATUS OF ENDANGERED WILDLIFE IN CANADA, STRATEGIC PLANNING BY THE EASTERN HABITAT JOINT VENTURE, AND ASSESSMENTS BY THE NATIONAL MARSHBIRD MONITORING PROGRAM.

CLIMATE CHANGE IS IMPACTING OCEAN CONDITIONS AND MARINE ANIMALS IN ALASKA THROUGH WARMING TEMPERATURES, CHANGING SEA ICE, AND OCEAN ACIDIFICATION. RECENTLY, MASSIVE MARINE HEATWAVES IN THE NORTH PACIFIC WERE LINKED TO SEABIRD DIE OFFS OF UNPRECEDENTED SCOPE. OCEAN WARMING CONDITIONS ARE RESULTING IN INCREASED HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOM (HAB) EVENTS, WITH ALGAL TOXINS DETECTED IN MULTIPLE SPECIES OF THE OCEAN FOOD WEB, INCLUDING MARINE MAMMALS. AS A UNIQUE, COLD WATER RESEARCH FACILITY WITH DECADES OF EXPERIENCE HOUSING, REHABILITATING, AND RESEARCHING NORTH PACIFIC MARINE MAMMALS AND SEABIRDS, IN THIS PROJECT THE ALASKA SEALIFE CENTER (ASLC) IS PROPOSING TO CONDUCT RESEARCH TO UNDERSTAND IMPACTS OF CHANGING OCEAN CONDITIONS ON MARINE SPECIES BY CONDUCTING CONTROLLED EXPERIMENTS AND DEVELOPING INDICATORS FOR MONITORING OCEAN AND ANIMAL HEALTH IN SEABIRDS AND MARINE MAMMALS. ADDITIONALLY, ASLC WILL DEVELOP CAPACITIES AND CULTIVATE PARTNERSHIPS FOR COLLABORATIONS ON SURVEILLANCE AND RESPONSE TO EMERGING THREATS RELATING TO SEABIRDS AND MARINE MAMMALS. THE PROGRAM SERVES AS A FOUNDATIONAL EFFORT TO SYNTHESIZE CURRENT STATE OF KNOWLEDGE, GENERATE NEW UNDERSTANDING ABOUT HEALTH INDICATORS, AND FORM PARTNERSHIPS TO FACILITATE AND STRENGTHEN MARINE ANIMAL HEALTH RESEARCH AND SURVEILLANCE IN ALASKA. THE PROGRAM AIMS TO ADDRESS NEEDS AND CONCERNS OF COMMUNITIES, RESOURCE MANAGERS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS OF MARINE ANIMAL HEALTH.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) IS THE LEAD FEDERAL AGENCY TASKED WITH PROMULGATING REGULATIONS THAT ENSURE THE SUSTAINABILITY OF PROTECTED BIRD SPECIES WHILE STREAMLINING ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS AND PROVIDING GREATER PREDICTABILITY OF THE REVIEW PROCESS FOR REGULATED INDUSTRIES. FOR MANY SPECIES, IT IS CHALLENGING TO DEVELOP ACCURATE ESTIMATES OF POPULATION TRENDS AT HIGH (I.E., LANDSCAPE SCALE) SPATIAL RESOLUTIONS ACROSS SPECIES RANGES BECAUSE OF GAPS IN DATA COVERAGE. CURRENTLY, THE ONLY AVAILABLE DATA FOR GENERATING FWS TREND ESTIMATES FOR MANY SPECIES COME FROM THE NORTH AMERICAN BREEDING BIRD SURVEY (BBS), A LONG-TERM VOLUNTEER SURVEY RUN BY THE USGS. BBS DATA HAVE SEVERAL KNOWN COVERAGE GAPS AND LIMITED REGIONAL-SCALE SPATIAL RESOLUTION. THE LABORATORY OF ORNITHOLOGY AT CORNELL UNIVERSITY MANAGES THE CITIZEN-SCIENCE DRIVEN EBIRD PROGRAM, WHICH ACCUMULATES TREMENDOUS VOLUMES OF INFORMATION ON BIRD OCCURRENCE AND ABUNDANCE THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES AND ELSEWHERE. CORNELL UNIVERSITY SCIENTISTS HAVE DEVELOPED RIGOROUS MODELS TO GENERATE RANGE-WIDE ESTIMATES OF POPULATION TRENDS WITH HIGH SPATIAL RESOLUTION FROM EBIRD DATA WHILE ACCOUNTING FOR THE CHALLENGES INHERENT IN THE ANALYSIS OF CITIZEN-SCIENCE DATA INCLUDING INTERANNUAL CONFOUNDING. IN PREVIOUS COLLABORATIONS, THE FWS AND CORNELL UNIVERSITY HAVE SHOWN HOW INTEGRATING EBIRD DATA COULD BE USED TO IMPROVE TREND ESTIMATES FOR MOTTLED DUCKS BY FILLING TEMPORAL GAPS IN AERIAL SURVEY DATA. BUILDING ON THE POSITIVE RESULTS FROM THESE PREVIOUS COLLABORATIONS, THE FWS INTENDS TO FURTHER COLLABORATE WITH THE CORNELL UNIVERSITY LABORATORY OF ORNITHOLOGY TO DEVELOP A GENERAL MODELING FRAMEWORK TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY AND RESOLUTION OF POPULATION TREND ESTIMATES BY INTEGRATING BBS AND EBIRD DATA. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THIS COLLABORATION IS TO PROVIDE MORE ACCURATE AND DETAILED INFORMATION ON POPULATION TRENDS FOR MANY BIRD SPECIES ACROSS THE UNITED STATES. THIS INFORMATION WILL FILL IMPORTANT DATA GAPS PROVIDING THE SERVICE WITH A MORE COMPREHENSIVE AND DETAILED UNDERSTANDING OF BIRD POPULATIONS NECESSARY TO CRAFT MORE PRECISE AND EFFECTIVE POLICIES. THIS FRAMEWORK WILL BE EVALUATED BY SIMULATION STUDIES AND VALIDATION WITH INDEPENDENT DATASETS (SUPPLIED BY THE FWS) ANALYZING SPECIES RELEVANT TO FWS MANAGEMENT APPLICATIONS.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) IS THE LEAD FEDERAL AGENCY TASKED WITH PROMULGATING REGULATIONS THAT PROVIDE GREATER CERTAINTY TO REGULATED INDUSTRIES, STREAMLINE ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEWS, AND ENSURE THE SUSTAINABILITY OF PROTECTED MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES. THE LABORATORY OF ORNITHOLOGY AT CORNELL UNIVERSITY MANAGES THE CITIZEN SCIENCE DRIVEN EBIRD PROGRAM, WHICH ACCUMULATES TREMENDOUS VOLUMES OF INFORMATION ON BIRD OCCURRENCE THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES AND ELSEWHERE. CORNELL UNIVERSITY SCIENTISTS HAVE DEVELOPED RIGOROUS MODELS TO GENERATE OCCURRENCE AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE INFORMATION FROM EBIRD DATA. THE FWS AND CORNELL UNIVERSITY HAVE PREVIOUSLY COLLABORATED ON CURRENT POLICY RECOMMENDATIONS THAT USE THESE EBIRD STATUS   TRENDS (S T) DATA PRODUCTS ON BALD AND GOLDEN EAGLES TO ASSESS LOW-RISK COLLISION AREAS FOR WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT. GIVEN THE POSITIVE RESULTS FROM THESE PREVIOUS COLLABORATIONS, THE FWS INTENDS TO FURTHER COLLABORATE WITH THE CORNELL UNIVERSITY LABORATORY OF ORNITHOLOGY TO PROVIDE RESULTS THAT COULD BE USED TO INFORM RISK ASSESSMENT AND INCIDENTAL TAKE REGULATIONS UNDER THE REVISED MIGRATORY BIRD TREATY ACT (MBTA), WITH THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF PROVIDING A MORE COMPLETE PERSPECTIVE ON POTENTIAL BIODIVERSITY IMPACTS OF INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT. USING RAPTORS AS AN EXAMPLE SPECIES GROUP, CURRENT ALLOWABLE TAKE LIMITS AND INDUSTRY PROJECT PERMITS (E.G., RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT) ARE ONLY DEVELOPED FOR GOLDEN EAGLES, PEREGRINE FALCONS, AND BALD EAGLES. HOWEVER, ONGOING CHANGES TO THE MBTA WILL REQUIRE THE FWS TO DEVELOP HIGH-RESOLUTION, COMPREHENSIVE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR MANY OTHER SPECIES AND SPECIES GROUPS. THE COMPREHENSIVE YEAR-ROUND DATA PRODUCTS GENERATED UNDER THIS COLLABORATION HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO IMPROVE THE SERVICE S ABILITY TO GUIDE POLICIES FOR 1) DEFINING HIGH-RESOLUTION, LOW RISK AREAS FOR RENEWABLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE AND 2) IDENTIFYING LOCATION- AND SPECIES-SPECIFIC MITIGATION MEASURES TO OFFSET TAKE FROM ANTHROPOGENIC SOURCES.

MID ELEVATIONS IN CENTRAL AND SOUTH AMERICA ARE HOME TO ONE OF THE MOST DIVERSE COMMUNITIES OF ANIMALS ON THE PLANET. FORESTED HABITATS AT MID ELEVATIONS ALSO SUPPORT THE GREATEST SPECIES RICHNESS AND ABUNDANCE OF MIGRATORY SONGBIRDS IN THE REGION. AMONG THE SONGBIRDS THAT DEPEND ON MID ELEVATION FORESTS DURING THE NON BREEDING PERIOD ARE SEVERAL STEEPLY DECLINING SPECIES, INCLUDING THE OLIVE SIDED FLYCATCHER, GOLDEN WINGED WARBLER CERULEAN WARBLER AND CANADA WARBLER. GIVEN THE ABOVE, A DIVERSE SET OF STAKEHOLDERS REPRESENTING OVER 79 ORGANIZATIONS INSTITUTIONS FROM ACROSS CENTRAL AND NORTHERN SOUTH AMERICA WERE BROUGHT TOGETHER IN A SERIES OF CONSERVATION STANDARDS WORKSHOPS IN EARLY 2021 TO CREATE A CONSERVATION INVESTMENT STRATEGY FOR MID ELEVATION FORESTS. AMONG THE RESULTING OBJECTIVES OF THE PLAN WAS THE PROTECTION OF HABITAT FOR THE THREE TARGET SPECIES (GOLDEN WINGED, CERULEAN AND CANADA WARBLERS) AS A STRATEGY FOR HALTING DECLINES. DEFORESTATION IS ONGOING IN THE REGION AND URGENT ACTION IS REQUIRED TO AVOID FURTHER HABITAT LOSS. TO COMBAT THIS LOSS, ONE OF THE OBJECTIVES OF THE CONSERVATION INVESTMENT STRATEGY IS TO INCREASE THE COVERAGE OF REMAINING MID ELEVATION FORESTS WITHIN PROTECTED AREAS TO 30  OF THE TOTAL AREA AND REDUCE DEFORESTATION RATES TO 1  OF THE CURRENT FOREST AREA OVER THE NEXT 10 YEARS. TO CONTRIBUTE TO THIS OBJECTIVE, THIS PROJECT WILL UNDERTAKE A RIGOROUS CHARACTERIZATION OF THE REMAINING MID ELEVATION FORESTS THROUGH A PARTICIPATORY PROCESS WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND NATIONAL AND REGIONAL ENVIRONMENT AUTHORITIES, AND UNDERTAKE THE NECESSARY STEPS TO CREATE ONE NEW PROTECTED AREA. TO NARROW DOWN THE GEOGRAPHICAL SCOPE OF THE PROJECT, THE EASTERN ANDES OF COLOMBIA WERE SELECTED, GIVEN THEIR LINKS WITH DECLINING POPULATIONS OF CANADA AND CERULEAN WARBLER.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OWNS AND MANAGES 70 ISLANDS AS PART OF THE MAINE COASTAL ISLANDS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. MANY SPECIES OF COLONIAL NESTING SEABIRDS WERE LARGELY EXTIRPATED FROM MAINE IN THE LATE 1800S THROUGH OVER-EXPLOITATION. FOLLOWING SOME RECOVERY BY THE 1930S AND 40S, MANY SPECIES AGAIN DECLINED AS NUMBERS OF HERRING GULLS (LARUS ARGENTATUS) AND GREAT BLACK-BACKED GULLS (LARUS MARINUS) INCREASED BECAUSE THEY WERE SUBSIDIZED BY HUMAN ACTIVITIES. THROUGH THE COOPERATIVE EFFORTS OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE MAINE DEPARTMENT OF INLAND FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE, AND THE NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY (WHICH WAS ACTIVE ON SOME OF THE REFUGE S ISLANDS PRIOR TO U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ACQUISITION), DIVERSE SEABIRD COLONIES HAVE BEEN RESTORED ON 12 ISLANDS IN THE GULF OF MAINE, 6 REFUGE ISLANDS, 4 STATE-OWNED ISLANDS, AND AN ISLAND OWNED BY NATIONAL AUDUBON SOCIETY. THE PARTNERS COORDINATE THEIR ACTIVITIES THROUGH MEETINGS OF THE GULF OF MAINE SEABIRD WORKING GROUP.IN THIS PROJECT, WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE PROTECTING SEABIRDS AT SEAL ISLAND NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, POND ISLAND NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, AND MATINICUS ROCK, AS WELL AS PARTICIPATE WITH THE REFUGE AND OTHER GULF OF MAINE SEABIRD MANAGERS IN STUDYING SEABIRD POPULATION TRENDS AND META-POPULATION DYNAMICS, NEST PRODUCTIVITY, CHICK PROVISIONING STUDIES, AND FORAGING AND MIGRATION RESEARCH.

VAST AREAS OF THE PNW REMAIN DATA DEFICIENT WITH RESPECT TO THE ESTIMATED MORE THAN 750 WILD BEE SPECIES THAT PROVIDE ESSENTIAL ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THERE. THE OREGON BEE ATLAS IS WORKING WITH EXPERT VOLUNTEER MASTER MELITTOLOGISTS TO ADDRESS THESE DEFICITS BY CONDUCTING INTENSIVE MULTI-METHOD INVENTORY AND MONITORING FIELD WORK THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND WITH A SPECIAL FOCUS IN GRASSLAND AND SAGEBRUSH HABITATS DUE TO THEIR RICH BIODIVERSITY. THIS FIELD WORK GENERATES SPECIES OCCURRENCE DATA, DATA ON COMMUNITY ASSEMBLAGE, ECOLOGICAL DATA ON BEE-FLORAL RELATIONS, AND COLLECTS GENETIC MATERIAL FOR HUNDREDS OF POLLINATOR SPECIES. THIS INFORMS CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OF SPECIES-AT-RISK, INFORMS SPECIES ASSESSMENTS, AND FILLS MASSIVE DATA GAPS FOR THESE BIODIVERSE AREAS.THE OREGON BEE ATLAS IS WORKING WITH EXPERT VOLUNTEER MASTER 4 MELITTOLOGISTS TO ADDRESS THESE DEFICITS BY CONDUCTING INTENSIVE MULTI-METHOD INVENTORY AND MONITORING FIELD WORKTHROUGHOUT THE STATE AND WITH A SPECIAL FOCUS IN GRASSLAND AND SAGEBRUSH HABITATS DUE TO THEIR RICH BIODIVERSITY.THIS FIELD WORK GENERATES SPECIES OCCURRENCE DATA, DATA ON COMMUNITY ASSEMBLAGE, ECOLOGICAL DATA ON BEE-FLORALRELATIONS, AND COLLECTS GENETIC MATERIAL FOR HUNDREDS OF POLLINATOR SPECIES. THIS INFORMS CONSERVATION ANDRESTORATION OF SPECIES-AT-RISK, INFORMS SPECIES ASSESSMENTS, AND FILLS MASSIVE DATA GAPS FOR THESE BIODIVERSE AREAS.THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO:1) PUBLISH A SPECIES OCCURRENCE DATASET FOR BOMBUS TO THE GLOBAL BIODIVERSITY INFORMATION FACILITY (GBIF) FROM VANETRAP SAMPLES, PAN TRAP SAMPLES, AND NETTED SAMPLES COLLECTED IN THE AREA IDENTIFIED IN FIGURE 1. BETWEEN 2019-2021, AND A SUMMARY DATA PAPER TO THE OREGON STATE ARTHROPOD COLLECTION JOURNAL, AND2) PROCESS 4 - 96 WELL PLATES OF BEE GENETIC MATERIAL (380 UNIQUE SPECIMENS LEFT SIDE MIDLEG) FOR COI MTDNABARCODING AT THE CANADIAN CENTRE FOR DNA BARCODING (CCDB), CENTRE FOR BIODIVERSITY GENOMICS, UNIVERSITY OFGUELPH, FOR PUBLIC RELEASE AS A BARCODE LIBRARY CONTRIBUTION.THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE SELECTED PRIORITIES BY 1) GENERATING SPECIES OCCURRENCE AND GENETIC DATA FOR POLLINATORS INGRASSLAND AND SAGEBRUSH HABITATS, 2) GENERATING DATA WHICH INFORMS SPECIES AND COMMUNITY CONSERVATION TOENHANCE CLIMATE RESILIENCY, 3) GENERATING DATA WHICH FILLS SIGNIFICANT KNOWLEDGE GAPS RELATED TO AT-RISK POLLINATORS,THEIR ECOLOGY AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, 4) GENERATING DATA WHICH PROVIDES INFORMATION NECESSARY TO INFORM DECISIONMAKING FOR REGIONAL AND NATIONAL CONSERVATION PRIORITIES, 5) GENERATING DATA WHICH IS THE RELIABLE SCIENCE NEEDED TOSUPPORT PROGRAMS AND PARTNERS, AND 6) GENERATING DATA WHICH IS PUBLISHED GLOBALLY FOLLOWING BEST PRACTICES.THE PROJECT OUTCOMES ARE SPECIFICALLY, PRIMARY SOURCES OF INFORMATION THAT CAN BE CONSULTED DIRECTLY FORSPATIOTEMPORAL, ECOLOGICAL, AND GENETIC DATA ON SPECIES-AT-RISK, HABITAT, AND FLORAL SPECIALISTS, AND RARE OR LITTLEKNOWN SPECIES IN GRASSLAND AND SAGEBRUSH HABITATS. MANAGERS CAN USE THIS INFORMATION TO CONSERVE THESE SPECIESAND THEIR INTERDEPENDENT FLORA OR ENHANCE THESE SPECIES THROUGH RESTORATION ACTION.

THE MOTUS WILDLIFE TRACKING SYSTEM (MOTUS) IS A DOI-SUPPORTED COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH NETWORK THAT USES COORDINATED AUTOMATED RADIO TELEMETRY ARRAYS TO STUDY THE MOVEMENTS OF SMALL-BODIED ANIMALS. WE ARE INSTALLING MOTUS STATIONS TO ENHANCE AN INITIAL FWS-LED EFFORT TO BEGIN BUILDING A NETWORK OF MOTUS STATIONS IN THE GREAT PLAINS TO ADDRESS QUESTIONS ABOUT THE MIGRATORY ECOLOGY FOR PRIORITY GRASSLAND BIRD SPECIES. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WOULD SUPPORT INSTALLATION OF MOTUS STATIONS, TRAPPING AND DEPLOYMENT OF MOTUS TAGS ON PRIORITY GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS IN THE GREAT PLAINS. THE ADDITIONAL STATIONS AND TAGS WILL HELP THE GREAT PLAINS MOTUS COLLABORATIVE (GPMC) REACH OUR INITIAL GOAL FOR COVERAGE OF STATIONS IN THE GEOGRAPHY THAT SUPPORT MIGRATING FOCAL GRASSLAND BIRD SPECIES. THESE DATA WILL GREATLY ENHANCE THE CONNECTIVITY OF THE NETWORK AND INCREASE DETECTIONS OF GRASSLAND BIRDS THAT FWS AND PARTNERS WILL BE TAGGING IN THE NORTHERN GREAT PLAINS IN 2023-2024 (AND BEYOND). THE DELIVERABLES ARE INSTALLED MOTUS STATIONS, DEPLOYMENT OF MOTUS TAGS ON GRASSLAND BIRDS ON THE NONBREEDING GROUNDS, AND A FINAL REPORT ABOUT THE WORK. THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM INSTALLING MOTUS STATIONS AND THE DATA THEY WILL COLLECT WILL ENABLE US TO DELIVER MORE STRATEGIC CONSERVATION THROUGH THE USFWS AND PARTNERS AND HELP STABILIZE OR REVERSE POPULATION DECLINES OF GRASSLAND BIRDS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE.

LESS THAN 40  OF THE HISTORICAL ACREAGE OF NORTH AMERICAN GRASSLANDS REMAINS TODAY. CONCOMITANTLY, GRASSLAND BIRDS HAVE DECLINED PRECIPITOUSLY. SPECIES THAT OVERWINTER IN THE CHIHUAHUAN DESERT GRASSLANDS HAVE DECLINED IN ABUNDANCE BY NEARLY 70 . HOWEVER, THE RESOURCES USED AND NEEDED BY THESE WINTERING SPECIES ARE NOT WELL STUDIED AND THUS CANNOT CURRENTLY BE MANAGED TO IMPROVE THESE SPECIES  POPULATIONS. ALTHOUGH THE CHIHUAHUAN GRASSLANDS ARE RELATIVELY WET COMPARED TO OTHER DESERT ECOSYSTEMS, WATER IS STILL A VALUABLE RESOURCE. LIVESTOCK TANKS ARE ONE IMPORTANT RESOURCE FOR MIGRATORY AND WINTERING BIRDS IN THE CHIHUAHUAN GRASSLANDS, ESPECIALLY BECAUSE PRECIPITATION IS INFREQUENT DURING THE WINTER. HOWEVER, MOST RESEARCH ON THE MANAGEMENT OF WORKING LANDS FOR NONBREEDING GRASSLAND BIRDS HAS FOCUSED ON GRAZING PRACTICES, AND LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE CHARACTERISTICS OF WATER SOURCES THAT ARE MOST SUITABLE FOR MIGRATING AND WINTERING BIRDS. OUR PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE SUITABILITY OF LIVESTOCK TANKS AND EPHEMERAL PONDS FOR MIGRATING AND WINTERING BIRDS IN THE TRANS-PECOS ECOREGION OF TEXAS. WE WILL USE AUTOMATED RECORDING UNITS AND POINT COUNTS TO EVALUATE PRIORITY SPECIES USE OF LIVESTOCK TANKS AND WILL MEASURE TANK CHARACTERISTICS INCLUDING SIZE, DISTANCE TO OTHER WATER SOURCES, AND SHRUB DENSITY ON THE SURROUNDING LANDSCAPE. WE WILL ALSO DEPLOY GSM TRANSMITTERS ON LONG-BILLED CURLEWS (NUMENIUS AMERICANUS) TO DOCUMENT THEIR MOVEMENTS THROUGHOUT THE WINTER AND BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW DIFFERENT RESOURCES IN THE CHIHUAHUAN GRASSLANDS ARE CONNECTED. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL DIRECTLY INFORM MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN THE TRANS-PECOS ECOREGION.

CONIFER REMOVAL AND MANAGEMENT IS A KEY TOOL FOR RESTORING SAGEBRUSH AND GRASSLAND ECOSYSTEMS AND GREATER SAGE-GROUSE, MULE DEER AND ELK POPULATIONS, AND MITIGATE FIRE RISK. THE EFFECTIVENESS OF MANAGEMENT HAS PRIMARILY BEEN MEASURED BY ACRES OF SAGEBRUSH RESTORED AND RESPONSE OF GREATER SAGE-GROUSE, MULE DEER, ELK, AND OTHER METRICS. THE RESPONSE OF VEGETATION AND PINYON JAYS TO CONIFER MANAGEMENT HAS NOT BEEN WELL-STUDIED. FOR EXAMPLE, THE DIRECT AND INDIRECT EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT AND OR REMOVAL OF OLDER, MAST PRODUCING PINON-JUNIPER WOODLANDS IN THE ECOTONE WITH SAGEBRUSH ON PINYON JAYS IS NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD. QUANTIFYING PINYON JAY RESPONSE TO CONIFER MANAGEMENT IN SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS WILL IMPROVE CONSERVATION DELIVERY BY ENSURING AGENCIES ACHIEVE OBJECTIVES WITHIN SAGEBRUSH WHILE MINIMIZING NEGATIVE IMPACTS, AND POTENTIALLY IMPROVING HABITAT CONDITIONS, FOR PINYON JAYS IN THESE OVERLAPPING, TRANSITIONAL ECOSYSTEMS.

CONIFER REMOVAL AND MANAGEMENT IS A KEY TOOL FOR RESTORING SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS AND GREATER SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS. THE EFFECTIVENESS OF MANAGEMENT HAS PRIMARILY BEEN MEASURED BY ACRES OF SAGEBRUSH RESTORED AND RESPONSE OF GREATER SAGE-GROUSE. THE RESPONSE OF VEGETATION AND PINYON JAYS TO CONIFER MANAGEMENT HAS NOT BEEN WELL-STUDIED. FOR EXAMPLE, THE DIRECT AND INDIRECT EFFECTS OF MANAGEMENT AND OR REMOVAL OF OLDER, MAST PRODUCING PINON-JUNIPER WOODLANDS IN THE ECOTONE WITH SAGEBRUSH ON PINYON JAYS IS NOT WELL UNDERSTOOD. QUANTIFYING PINYON JAY RESPONSE TO CONIFER MANAGEMENT IN SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEMS WILL IMPROVE CONSERVATION DELIVERY BY ENSURING AGENCIES ACHIEVE OBJECTIVES WITHIN SAGEBRUSH WHILE MINIMIZING NEGATIVE IMPACTS, AND POTENTIALLY IMPROVING HABITAT CONDITIONS, FOR PINYON JAYS IN THESE OVERLAPPING, TRANSITIONAL ECOSYSTEMS.

COMMON GOLDENEYES (BUCEPHALA CLANGULA, HEREAFTER GOLDENEYE) ARE A SPECIES OF CAVITY NESTING SEA DUCK THAT ALMOST EXCLUSIVELY BREED IN BOREAL FOREST SYSTEMS. THE GOLDENEYE S RANGE IN NORTH AMERICA EXTENDS FROM WEST-CENTRAL ALASKA, ACROSS CANADIAN FORESTS, AND INTO THE NORTHERN TIER OF THE UNITED STATES. AS PART OF A MITIGATION PROJECT IN 1994, THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS ESTABLISHED APPROXIMATELY 150 NEST BOXES, PRIMARILY TO ATTRACT COMMON GOLDENEYES, WITHIN THE CHENA RIVER STATE RECREATION AREA. THIS IS LARGELY A 102 KM2 SYSTEM ALONG THE NORTH AND MIDDLE FORKS OF THE CHENA RIVER AND DATA HAVE BEEN COLLECTED FROM NEST BOXES NEARLY CONTINUOUSLY FOR OVER 25 YEARS.TO ASSESS THE PRODUCTIVITY, SURVIVAL, FIDELITY, AND AGE-STRUCTURE POPULATION DYNAMICS (ALL IMPORTANT TO UNDERSTANDING DEMOGRAPHY OF A SPECIES) OF A SEA DUCK AT THE NORTHERN LIMIT OF ITS BREEDING RANGE, THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ESTABLISHED THE COMMON GOLDENEYE NESTING ECOLOGY STUDY IN THE INTERIOR ALASKA IN 1997. THE PRIMARY CONCERN IS TO UNDERSTAND HOW CAVITY-NESTING COMMON GOLDENEYES ARE INFLUENCED BY ANNUAL AND LONG-TERM SHIFTS IN CLIMATE CHANGE. TWO OTHER IMPORTANT ASPECTS OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE, A) PROVIDE UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE TRAINING IN LEADERSHIP, WATERFOWL ECOLOGY, AND DECISION-MAKING, AND B) INCREASE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING, AWARENESS, AND SUPPORT FOR WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT AND WETLAND CONSERVATION.FIELD WORK WILL OCCUR ON THE CHENA RIVER STATE RECREATION AREA AND THE CHENA RIVER FLOOD CONTROL PROJECT. FIELD SEASON WILL OCCUR FROM APPROXIMATELY 15 MAY THROUGH 1 JULY 2023. BY MAY 17, 2023, APPROXIMATELY 200 NEST BOXES WILL BE MONITORED TO ESTABLISH NEST BOX USE BY SPECIES, LEG-BANDING AND MEASURING BREEDING FEMALE DUCKS AND OWLS, AND WEB-TAGGING DUCKLINGS AND OWLETS AS THEY HATCH. DR. J. BRIAN DAVIS, PRINCIPLE INVESTIGATOR AND THE JAMES C. KENNEDY ENDOWED PROFESSOR IN WATERFOWL AND WETLANDS CONSERVATION AT MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY, WILL BE LEAD COLLABORATOR REPRESENTING MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY. GRADUATE STUDENT (MS) RILEY PORTER AND UNDERGRADUATE LOGAN WILLIAMSON WILL COLLECT FIELD DATA DURING THE SPECIFIED TIMELINES. THE PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES COLLABORATION AND COORDINATION WITH PERSONNEL FROM THE STATE OF ALASKA DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, STATE PARKS, CHENA RIVER STATE RECREATION AREA, AND THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS CHENA RIVER FLOOD CONTROL PROJECT. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL MONITOR THE PROGRESS OF FIELD WORK EVERY WEEK. IN ADDITION, PERSONNEL WILL VISIT THE FIELD STATION TO ENSURE DATA COLLECTION PROTOCOLS ARE BEING ADHERED TO THROUGHOUT THE FIELD SEASON.THE EXPECTED DELIVERABLES ARE A COMPLETE AND QUALITY CONTROLLED-CHECKED DATA SET AND A FIELD REPORT. THERE WILL ALSO BE OPPORTUNITIES WITH LOCAL MEDIA TO CREATE AWARENESS TO THE PROJECT AND EDUCATE THE PUBLIC AND OTHERS. ULTIMATELY, GRADUATE STUDENT RILEY PORTER WILL PRODUCE A MASTER OF SCIENCE THESIS WORTHY OF MEETING THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE GRADUATE SCHOOL OF MISSISSIPPI STATE UNIVERSITY, AN NSF RECOGNIZED, CARNEGIE, AND R1 RESEARCH INSTITUTION. THE LONG-TERM NATURE OF THIS PROJECT ON THIS IMPORTANT SPECIES OF SEA DUCK WILL CREATE KNOWLEDGE THAT IS UNIQUE TO THE FIELD OF WATERFOWL ECOLOGY, MANAGEMENT, AND SPECIES CONSERVATION.

THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ (HEREAFTER, UCSC) WILL ASSIST THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE(HEREAFTER, SERVICE) WITH SURVEYING BREEDING COLONIES OF THE COMMON MURRE (URIA AALGE), BRANDTS CORMORANT (URILEPENICILLATUS), AND DOUBLE-CRESTED CORMORANT (NANNOPTERUM AURITUM). TO PROVIDE UPDATED BREEDING POPULATION SIZEINFORMATION FOR THESE SPECIES, AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHIC SURVEYS OF BREEDING COLONIES WILL BE CONDUCTED USINGSTANDARDIZED METHODS AND SEASONAL TIMING (PEAK OF THE BREEDING SEASON) DEVELOPED FROM PAST YEARS. PHOTOGRAPHSWILL BE TAKEN FROM A HIGH WING, FIXED-WING AIRCRAFT USING HIGH RESOLUTION DIGITAL CAMERAS AND TELEPHOTO LENSES.COUNTS OF SEABIRDS FROM AERIAL PHOTOGRAPHS WILL FOLLOW STANDARD METHODS DESCRIBED IN THE SERVICES NATIONALPROTOCOL FRAMEWORK FOR MONITORING COMMON MURRE AND BRANDTS CORMORANT BREEDING COLONIES IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT SYSTEM AND OTHER REPORTS, INCLUDING COUNTING AND ENUMERATING NEST AND BIRD NUMBERS WITH COMPUTER SOFTWARE. IN 2023, SURVEYS WILL BE FOCUSED ON COLONIES IN THE GULF OF THE FARALLONES, WITH COUNTS FROM PHOTOGRAPHS DETERMINED FOR THE COLONIES AT THE NORTH AND SOUTH FARALLON ISLANDS. ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR ADDITIONAL SURVEYS AND IMAGE ANALYSES IS EXPECTED THROUGH THE 5-YEAR AGREEMENT PERIOD.

KING RAILS POPULATIONS ARE FRAGMENTED ALONG THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY. LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT CONNECTIVITY AND GENETIC RELATEDNESS AMONG POPULATIONS. THERE HAVE BEEN NO HUNTING RECORDS FOR KING RAILS IN RECENT YEARS, AND IN THE ABSENCE OF A PARTS SURVEY, IT HAS BEEN DIFFICULT TO OBTAIN SAMPLES OF THIS SPECIES FROM OTHER SITES FOR POPULATION-LEVEL ANALYSES. THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH OTHER UNIVERSITY RESEARCHERS, WE ARE NOW ABLE TO SCALE OUR ANALYSES UP TO THE LEVEL OF THE SPECIES RANGE. OUR STUDY WILL CONTRIBUTE VALUABLE INFORMATION ABOUT THE GENETIC STRUCTURE AND DEGREE OF CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN RESIDENT POPULATIONS SITUATED HUNDREDS OF MILES APART. BY COLLECTING SAMPLES FROM KING RAILS IN SOUTH CAROLINA TO COMPARE WITH POPULATIONS IN NORTH CAROLINA AND FLORIDA, AS WELL AS INLAND POPULATIONS IN OHIO AND ARKANSAS, ACQUIRED THROUGH COLLABORATION, WE WILL DETERMINE IF HOW POPULATIONS REMAIN CONNECTED THROUGH MIGRATION DISPERSAL, OR IF ISOLATED, WE WILL ESTIMATE FOR HOW LONG. WE WILL ALSO DETERMINE THE DEGREE OF INTROGRESSION OF CLAPPER RAIL GENES, IF ANY. A HIGH-RESOLUTION WHOLE GENOME OF THE CLAPPER RAIL IS NOW AVAILABLE3 AND WILL SERVE AS A SCAFFOLD FOR OUR GENOME COMPARISONS. USING INTER-POPULATION COMPARISONS TO ASSESS LEVELS OF GENE FLOW, MIGRATORY STATUS AND RELATIVE POPULATION SIZE, AND ALSO TO EVALUATE THE LEVEL AND IMPACT OF HYBRIDIZATION WITH CLAPPER RAILS.

POPULATIONS OF AMERICAN WOODCOCK HAVE DECLINED FOR OVER HALF A CENTURY, AND THE AMERICAN WOODCOCK SINGING GROUND SURVEY (SGS) IS ONE OF THE PRIMARY DATASETS USED TO INFORM WOODCOCK MANAGEMENT. TO AVOID BIAS, THE SGS SHOULD BE TIMED TO AVOID PERIODS OF MIGRATION, AND THE DISTRIBUTION OF SURVEY ROUTES SHOULD COINCIDE WITH WOODCOCK BREEDING DISTRIBUTION. RECENT RESEARCH IN THE EASTERN WOODCOCK MANAGEMENT REGION USING GPS TRACKING OF MALE WOODCOCK SUGGESTS CURRENT SGS DESIGN IS LARGELY CONSISTENT WITH TIMING OF MIGRATION IN ALL BUT THE NORTHERNMOST LATITUDES. HOWEVER, THE NUMBER OF MALES THAT HAVE BEEN MARKED AND TRACKED IN THE CENTRAL MANAGEMENT REGION IS LIMITED. BECAUSE BREEDING AREAS IN THE WESTERN PORTION OF WOODCOCK RANGE OCCUR AT MORE NORTHERN LATITUDES THAN IN THE EASTERN MANAGEMENT REGION, IT IS POSSIBLE THAT MISMATCH BETWEEN THE SGS AND WOODCOCK MIGRATION MAY BE MORE EXTREME FOR THE CENTRAL MANAGEMENT REGION. WE PROPOSE TO LEVERAGE THE COLLABORATIVE NETWORK CREATED THROUGH THE EASTERN WOODCOCK MIGRATION RESEARCH COOPERATIVE (EWMRC  WWW.WOODCOCKMIGRATION.ORG) TO GPS-MARK MALE WOODCOCK IN WINTERING AREAS IN THE CENTRAL MANAGEMENT REGION AND BOLSTER THE SAMPLE OF SPRING MIGRANTS TO FURTHER ASSESS SGS TIMING AND COVERAGE. THESE BIRDS WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE GENOMIC SAMPLES TO ONGOING RESEARCH ON WOODCOCK POPULATION STRUCTURE, SUPPORTED BY PREVIOUS WEBLESS MIGRATORY GAME BIRD RESEARCH FUNDING. THIS PROPOSED WORK WILL RESULT IN A MANUSCRIPT PROVIDING AN ASSESSMENT OF SGS VALIDITY IN THE CENTRAL MANAGEMENT REGION, WHICH WILL BENEFIT WOODCOCK MANAGERS THROUGH IMPROVED APPLICATION OF THE SGS TO WOODCOCK CONSERVATION PRACTICES.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE INTENDS ENTER INTO A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH CONSERVE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION OF NEW JERSEY (CWF) TO MONITOR AND MANAGE PIPING PLOVERS AND OTHER BEACH NESTING BIRDS ON THE EDWIN B. FORSYTHE NWR (REFUGE) AND A NEWLY FORMED ADJACENT ISLAND (HORSESHOE ISLAND) FOR THE 2023 NESTING SEASON. CWF WILL CONDUCT TASKS TO INCLUDE  NEST SEARCHING, INCUBATION MONITORING, CHICK SEARCHES AND MONITORING, COLONY COUNTS, PREDATOR CONTROL SUPPORT, DATA COLLECTION, DATA ENTRY, AS WELL AS HABITAT AND PREDATOR SURVEYS AND OUTREACH, AS NEEDED. OTHER TASKS WILL INCLUDE  ASSURING DATA COLLECTED IN THE FIELD IS CORRECT AND ENTERED INTO ELECTRONIC DATABASES, WRITING PROGRESS REPORTS, SUBMITTING A FINAL REPORT, AND COMPILING AND SENDING ALL NESTING DATA TO FEDERAL AND STATE PARTNERS AT THE END OF THE NESTING SEASON. MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF HORSESHOE ISLAND WILL BE DONE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH NEW JERSEY FISH AND WILDLIFE   ENDANGERED AND NONGAME SPECIES PROGRAM. THE REFUGE WILL BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED IN PROJECTS UNDER THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY. INPARTICULAR, THE SERVICE WILL  (1) PROVIDE ASSISTANCE WITH TRANSPORTATION TO MONITORING AREAS BY PROVIDING THE USE OF REFUGE WATERCRAFT AND FUEL  (2) WORK WITH CWF TO ESTABLISH THE TIMING OF MONITORING  (3) DETERMINE SCOPE AND PRIORITIZING PROJECT ACTIVITIES IN THE EVENT OF BUDGET SHORTFALLS  (4) REVIEW DOCUMENTS TO ENSURE THAT ANY REQUIREMENTS FOR COMPLIANCE UNDER THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL POLICY ACT, SECTION 7 OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, AND SECTION 106 OF THE NATIONAL HISTORICPRESERVATION ACT ARE MET PRIOR TO CONDUCTING FIELD WORK  (5) PROVIDE SUPPLIES NECESSARY FOR MONITORING ACTIVITIES (E.G.,BINOCULARS AND SPOTTING SCOPES)  AND (6) PROVIDE HOUSING FOR CWF STAFF, AS AVAILABLE.

THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE USING EXPERIENCED AIRBOAT OPERATORS TO TRANSPORT OBSERVERS TO PARTS OF NORTHERN GRAYSHARBOR AND NORTHERN WILLAPA BAY, WASHINGTON, FOR A STUDY OF MIGRANT RED KNOTS. AIRBOATS ARE USED BY OBSERVERS TOCLOSELY APPROACH FLOCKS OF KNOTS, WHICH ARE THEN SCANNED USING SPOTTING SCOPES TO SEARCH FOR UNIQUELY CODED LEGBANDS ( FLAGS ). SIGHTINGS OF IDENTIFIED KNOTS WILL BE USED BY PROJECT PARTNERS TO DEVELOP ESTIMATES OF THE SIZEOF THE FLYWAY POPULATION OF KNOTS. THE TWO STUDY AREAS WILL EACH BE VISITED 10 TIMES BETWEEN LATE APRIL AND LATEMAY 2023. FUNDING FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO PAY THE AIRBOAT OPERATOR SALARY AND COVER FUEL COSTS FOR THETRANSPORT TRUCK AND THE AIRBOAT.

THE MEXICAN DUCK  ANAS DIAZI  IS NOT ONLY AN ENDEMIC RESIDENT OF THE CHIHUAHUAN DESERT OF INTERIOR MEXICO AND SOUTHWESTER USA, BUT IS ALSO ONE OF THE LEAST UNDERSTOOD SPECIES IN NORTH AMERICA  FIGURE 1 . WE PROPOSE TO USE THE LATEST TECHNOLOGIES AND METHODS IN UNDERSTANDING INDIVIDUAL MOVEMENT PATTERNS, AS WELL AS OVERALL POPULATION MOVEMENT ECOLOGY AND HABITAT REQUIREMENTS ACROSS THEIR SOUTHWESTERN DISTRIBUTION.

PILOT STUDY OUTCOMES IDENTIFY A NEED TO IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF RIPARIAN AND WETLAND, HEREAFTER  WETLAND , CHANGE IN NORTH AMERICAN WATERBIRD FLYWAYS. RESEARCHERS NOW SEEK TO EXPAND THEIR EFFORTS TO INCLUDE ALL OF THE PACIFIC FLYWAY AND PORTIONS OF THE CENTRAL FLYWAY IN THE WESTERN U.S. OUR ABILITY TO EFFICIENTLY QUANTIFY AND MONITOR FLYWAY CONDITIONS IS CRUCIAL TO COORDINATING MULTI-SCALE CONSERVATION PRACTICES NEEDED TO OFFSET WETLAND DECLINES. RESULTS WILL SUPPORT AN ADAPTIVE FRAMEWORK SHARED THROUGH THE WETLAND EVALUATION TOOL  WET , AN INTERACTIVE ONLINE MAPPING APPLICATION THAT SYNCHRONIZES WETLAND HABITAT CONDITIONS AND WATERBIRD DISTRIBUTIONS ACROSS TIME. PROJECT EXPANSION WILL CONSIST OF THREE COMPONENTS 1  ASSESSING WETLAND RESILIENCE  MEASURING IMPACTS OF FUNCTIONAL DECLINE  I.E., WETLAND DRYING  IN THE WESTERN U.S. - RESILIENCE WILL BE MEASURED BY MONITORING MONTHLY SURFACE WATER HYDROLOGY FROM 1984 TO PRESENT. THE ANALYSIS WILL PROVIDE THE FIRST-EVER EVALUATION OF CLIMATE INDUCED WETLAND CHANGE THROUGHOUT THE WEST. TRENDS WILL BE SUMMARIZED WITHIN LEVEL III EPA ECOREGIONS AND BINNED BY WETLAND HYDROPERIODS  I.E., SEMI-PERMANENT, SEASONAL, AND TEMPORARY , LAND OWNERSHIP, AND LAND-USE. ASSESSMENTS WILL INCLUDE AGRICULTURAL HABITATS  E.G., FLOOD IRRIGATED GRASS-HAY AND RICE . UNDERSTANDING WETLAND CHANGE IS ESSENTIAL TO ADAPTIVE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES THAT MAINTAIN FLYWAY FUNCTION. STUDY OUTCOMES WILL SUPPORT A CONSERVATION FRAMEWORK THAT PRIORITIZES THE PROTECTION OF CLIMATE-RESILIENT LANDSCAPES. CONVERSELY, IDENTIFYING CLIMATE VULNERABILITY IN SOME REGIONS WILL GUIDE TRIAGE AND RESTORATION STRATEGIES THAT MINIMIZE LONG-TERM IMPACTS. WETLAND CHANGE RESULTS WILL BE PROVIDED AS INTERACTIVE MAPS THROUGH WET.2  IDENTIFICATION OF CLIMATE-INDUCED WATERBIRD IMPACTS - EBIRD DATA WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE REGIONAL MIGRATION CHRONOLOGIES FOR APPROXIMATELY 30 WATERBIRD SPECIES REPRESENTING A DIVERSITYOF WETLAND HABITATS. SPECIES SELECTION WILL BE INFORMED THROUGH STAKEHOLDER INPUT TO ENSURE OUTCOMES ALIGN WITH PARTNER NEEDS. SPATIALLY EXPLICIT MIGRATION CHRONOLOGIES WILL BE CONSTRUCTED AROUND THE DISTRIBUTION OF PUBLIC WILDLIFE AREAS  I.E., WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS AND NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES  WHERE EBIRD OBSERVATIONS AND WETLANDS ARE TYPICALLY CLUSTERED. FOLLOWING THE METHODS OUTLINED BY DONNELLY  2022 , MIGRATION CHRONOLOGIES WILL BE LINKED TO MONTHLY WETLAND TRENDS TO MEASURE SPECIES- AND GEOGRAPHICALLYSPECIFIC HABITAT LOSSES OVER ANNUAL MIGRATION CYCLES  I.E., BREEDING, MIGRATION, WINTERING .SPATIALLY EXPLICIT MIGRATION CHRONOLOGIES AND WETLAND HABITAT TRENDS WILL BE PROVIDED AS INTERACTIVE MAPS THROUGH WET. OUTCOMES WILL SUPPORT A MULTI-SCALE ADAPTIVE FRAMEWORK THAT INFORMS WETLAND MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION BY LINKING FLYWAY HABITAT CHANGE TO REGIONAL WATERBIRD IMPACTS.

NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION  NFWF  ADVANCES THE PRIORITIES OF THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  FWS   MIGRATORY BIRDS THROUGH THE 2022 FWS URBAN BIRD TREATY PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM  FUNDING SUPPORTS PROJECTS SOLICITED  THROUGH THE FIVE STAR AND URBAN WATERS RESTORATION GRANT PROGRAM  THESE PROJECTS IMPROVE AND PROTECT FISH AND  WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITATS IN URBAN, SUBURBAN, AND RURAL COMMUNITIES, WHICH EXPAND OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUTDOOR  RECREATION TO ALL AMERICANS  NFWF LEVERAGES THESE FEDERAL DOLLARS WITH OTHER FEDERAL DOLLARS AS WELL AS PRIVATE  DOLLARS FROM SOUTHERN COMPANY AND FEDEX   A KEY ELEMENT OF THE FIVE STAR AND URBAN WATERS RESTORATION GRANT PROGRAM IS THE REQUIREMENT FOR SUB RECIPIENTS  TO ENGAGE FIVE  5  COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN EACH PROJECT  THIS REQUIREMENT FOSTERS PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS  WITHIN LOCAL COMMUNITIES  FURTHERMORE, PARTICIPATING CITIES MAY HAVE INTEREST IN BECOMING AN URBAN BIRD TREATY  CITY AFTER RECEIVING A GRANT

THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATIONWILL QUANTIFY THE EFFECT OF CONIFER MANAGEMENT AT VARIOUS SCALES ON SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS, PINYON JAYS, AND  VEGETATION IN THE EASTERN GREAT BASIN IN EASTERN NEVADA AND WESTERN UTAH IN A BEFORE AND AFTER  BACI  DESIGN  WE  PROPOSE TO CONDUCT SURVEYS AT LEAST ONE YEAR PRE TREATMENT AND TWO YEARS POST TREATMENT, WHERE POSSIBLE  WE WILL  DEVELOP A SAMPLING DESIGN TO MONITOR CHANGE IN BIRD ABUNDANCE AND DENSITY IN SAGE CORE AREAS AND GROWTH  OPPORTUNITY AREAS WHERE CONIFER MANAGEMENT IS PLANNED AND OR BEING IMPLEMENTED  WE WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS IN BOTH  INTACT SAGEBRUSH AND THE ECOTONE OF PHASE 2 PINON JUNIPER WOODLANDS, THE LATTER OF WHICH IS OFTEN TARGETED FOR  REMOVAL  WE WILL ALSO SAMPLE WITHIN THE LARGER AREA  WATERSHED  THAT INCLUDES BOTH TREATED AND UNTREATED SITES   THIS APPROACH WILL ALLOW US TO DIRECTLY MEASURE BIRD AND VEGETATION RESPONSE AT BOTH THE LOCAL PROJECT SCALE AND  AT A LARGER WATERSHED SCALE OVER TIME, WHILE ADDITIONAL MANAGEMENT IS BEING IMPLEMENTED IN THE AREA   WE WILL USE INTEGRATED MONITORING OF BIRD CONSERVATION REGIONS  IMBCR  SURVEY PROTOCOLS IN LATE MAY AND JUNE TO  MONITOR SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE SONGBIRDS AND QUANTIFY VEGETATION STRUCTURE  WE WILL USE STANDARDIZED JAY SURVEY  PROTOCOLS TO LOCATE JAYS FROM MARCH THROUGH MAY, WHICH IS THE JAY BREEDING SEASON  WE WILL OVERLAY SURVEYS IN  PHASE 1 AND 2 PINON JUNIPER WOODLANDS, WHICH ARE THE WOODLAND STRUCTURES OFTEN USED BY JAYS IN THE GREAT BASIN   WE WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS UP TO THREE TIMES PER SEASON, WITH AT LEAST TWO WEEKS BETWEEN VISITS, TO DETERMINE  OCCUPANCY AND HABITAT USE DURING THIS PERIOD  WE WILL SEEK TO DEPLOY AT LEAST 75 GPS TAGS ON PINYON JAYS ACROSS  AT LEAST THIRTEEN FLOCKS TO QUANTIFY FINE SCALE MOVEMENT AND HABITAT USE, AND HOW MANAGEMENT INFLUENCES THESE  BEHAVIORS  PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A PHD DISSERTATION AND PUBLICATION OF RESULTS  THIS WORK WILL AID IN  UNDERSTANDING IMPACTS OF WOODLAND MANAGEMENT ON SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE BIRDS AND PINYON JAYS  THE RESULTS WILL HELP  INFORM FUTURE CONSERVATION PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT IN SAGEBRUSH AND PINON JUNIPER WOODLAND ECOSYSTEMS AND THEIR  ECOTONE  THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL ENABLE US TO DELIVER MORE STRATEGIC CONSERVATION THROUGH THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS  AND PARTNERS AND  HELP STABILIZE OR REVERSE BIRD POPULATION DECLINES TO THE BENEFIT OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE

NORTHEAST MONTANA REPRESENTS CRITICAL, CORE BREEDING HABITAT FOR MANY OF OUR MOST IMPERILED  GRASSLAND SONGBIRD SPECIES  USFWS HAS BEEN WORKING CROSS PROGRAMMATICALLY AND WITH A BROAD  ARRAY OF EXTERNAL PARTNERSHIPS IN THIS REGION TO MAINTAIN AND ENHANCE HABITAT FOR THESE SPECIES   HOWEVER, TO DATE WE HAVE NOT ADEQUATELY MONITORED BIRDS  RESPONSE TO THESE INTERVENTIONS TO  DETERMINE IF AND HOW MUCH WE ARE BENEFITING POPULATIONS  THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THIS CRITICAL  NEED BY DEPLOYING ACOUSTIC RECORDERS THAT ALLOW US TO EFFICIENTLY MONITOR BIRD POPULATIONS BY  USING RECORDINGS OF THEIR SONGS  THE MAIN PROJECT DELIVERABLE IS ANNUAL MONITORING REPORTS

CONSERVING CONNECTIVITY IS FUNDAMENTAL TO SPECIES PERSISTENCE, YET RARELY IS MADE ACTIONABLE INTO SPATIAL PLANNING FOR IMPERILED SPECIES  CLIMATE CHANGE AND HABITAT DEGRADATION HAVE ADDED URGENCY TO INCORPORATE CONNECTIVITY INTO CONSERVATION PLANNING, PARTICULARLY INTO NETWORKS OF PROTECTED AREAS  IDENTIFYING LANDSCAPES WITH THE GREATEST CONTRIBUTION TO CONNECTIVITY, AND THEREFORE OF THE GREATEST PRIORITY FOR CONSERVATION IS PARAMOUNT TO ACTIONABLE MANAGEMENT  WE WILL INCORPORATE BOTH CONNECTIVITY AMONG CORE SAGEBRUSH AREAS AND WILDFIRE THREAT TO CORE SAGEBRUSH AREAS INTO THE WAFWA SAGEBRUSH CONSERVATION DESIGN  CROSSWINDS ECOLOGICAL CONSULTING LLC  WILL CREATE SPATIAL ACTION MAPS THAT IDENTIFY AREAS OF GREATEST FUNCTIONAL CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN CONSERVATION LANDSCAPES  E G , SAGEBRUSH CORE AREAS AND OR PRIORITY AREAS FOR CONSERVATION  BASED ON A PRIORITIZED CONNECTIVITY MAP EMPIRICALLY DERIVED FROM FOUNDATIONAL MODELS OF FUNCTIONAL AND NETWORK CONNECTIVITY  THESE HIGHEST PRIORITY CONNECTIVITY LANDSCAPES MAY SERVE TO IDENTIFY  A  STRONGHOLDS WITHIN CONSERVATION AREAS TO DEFEND AGAINST THREATS AND  B  GROWTH OPPORTUNITY AREAS THAT SERVE TO CONNECT THE SAGEBRUSH BIOME  WITHIN THE HIGHEST PRIORITY CONNECTIVITY LANDSCAPES, WE WILL CREATE SPATIAL ACTION MAPS THAT IDENTIFY WHERE THREATS  E G , CONIFER ENCROACHMENT AND AGRICULTURAL CONVERSION  EXCEED EMPIRICAL THRESHOLDS TO CONNECTIVITY FOR TARGETED THREAT MITIGATION WITH MAXIMIZED CONSERVATION RETURN  THESE AREAS WILL BE USED TO IDENTIFY CONSERVATION OPPORTUNITY AREAS WITHIN WHICH TO PRIORITIZE RIPARIAN RESTORATION AND PROTECTION, AS WELL AS TO FOCUS INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS AND CONIFER TREATMENTS

THE THREE ROSY-FINCH SPECIES, BLACK (LEUCOSTICTE ATRATA), BROWN-CAPPED (L. AUSTRALIS), AND GRAY-CROWNED (L. TEPHROCOTIS; HEREAFTER ROSY-FINCHES) ARE AMONG THE MOST CLIMATE-THREATENED SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES. ROSY-FINCHES BREED WITHIN HIGH ALPINE AND ARTIC TUNDRA BIOMES OF NORTH AMERICA, WHICH ARE PREDICTED TO BE DISPROPORTIONATELY IMPACTED BY CLIMATE CHANGE THROUGH INCREASED TEMPERATURES, REDUCED SNOWPACK AND PRECIPITATION, AND CHANGES IN PLANT COMMUNITIES. DURING WINTER, ROSY FINCHES OFTEN OCCUR TOTHER AND OCCUPY A BROADER RANGE OF HABITATS OF HIGH AND LOW ELEVATION AREAS WITH VARYING ANTHROPOGENIC DEVELOPMENT, AND READILY APPROACH ARTIFICIAL FEEDERS. WINTER FIELD STUDIES OFFER A VALUABLE OPPORTUNITY TO EFFICIENTLY ACQUIRE DEMOGRAPHIC DATA AND BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES FOR ALL THREE ROSY-FINCH SPECIES WITH A POTENTIALLY REDUCED LOGISTICAL OVERHEAD. OUR STUDY WILL LEVERAGE LONG-TERM MARK-RECAPTURE AND FEATHER SAMPLE DATASETS (2004-2022) FROM WINTERING ROSY FINCHES THE SANDIA CREST, NEW MEXICO, WHICH IS THE SOUTHERNMOST AREA IN WHICH ALL THREE SPECIES CO-OCCUR. WE WILL ANALYZER THE MARK-RECAPTURE DATA TO ESTIMATE OVERWINTER SURVIVAL AND ABUNDANCE, AND WILL USE THE FEATHER SAMPLES TO CONDUCT STABLE ISOTOPE ANALYSES TO EVALUATE THE BREEDING SITE ORIGIN OF EACH INDIVIDUAL. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL ALSO BEGIN MARKING CAPTURED BIRDS ON THE SANDIA CREST RADIO FREQUENCY IDENTIFICATION (RFID) LEG BANDS AND ESTABLISH A NETWORK OF RFID-FEEDERS THAT CAN SCAN AND RECORD BY BIRDS WITH RFID LEG BANDS. WE WILL EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF RFID-EQUIPPED FEEDERS TO IMPROVE SURVIVAL ESTIMATE PRECISION. THIS STUDY IS WELL-SITUATED TO FILL IN CRITICAL GAPS REGARDING ROSY FINCH DEMOGRAPHY, LIFE HISTORY, AND BREEDING DISTRIBUTION PATTERNS, THAT IS NEEDED TO DEVELOP COMPREHENSIVE CONSERVATION PLANS.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO ASSESS THREE DEMOGRAPHIC METRICS INFLUENCING PRODUCTIVITY - NEST DENSITY, NEST SUCCESS, AND ADULT DENSITY FOR REGIONAL PRIORITY GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS. WE WILL ASSESS SPECIES HABITAT ASSOCIATIONS AND VITAL RATES WITH BIOTIC FACTORS (E.G., LAND COVER, VEGETATION) AND ABIOTIC FACTORS (E.G., SOIL, TEMPERATURE, PRECIPITATION). ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL EXPLORE INTERACTIONS AMONGST THIS SUITE OF SPECIES AT MULTIPLE SCALES TO UNDERSTAND COMMUNITY DYNAMICS AND HOW HABITAT INFLUENCES AVIAN DIVERSITY(E.G., SPECIES RICHNESS AND ABUNDANCE). THESE DATA WILL HELP INFORM HOW POTENTIAL MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES AND HABITAT THREATS (E.G., WIND ENERGY DEVELOPMENT, WHICH HAS PLANNED SIGNIFICANT EXPANSION IN THE PROJECT AREA) AFFECT INDIVIDUAL SPECIES AND THE ENTIRE SUITE OF GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS. UNDERSTANDING BREEDING DEMOGRAPHICS OF THESE AVIAN SPECIES AND HOW THE DEMOGRAPHICS RELATE AMONGST SPECIES WILL BE CRITICAL TO MAINTAINING NECESSARY GRASSLAND CONDITIONS FOR THE SUITE OF GRASSLAND BIRDS WHILE INFORMING IMPROVED CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT IN THE AREAS WHERE SPECIES ARE DECLINING. PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A MASTER'S THESIS AND PUBLICATION OF RESULTS. THIS WORK WILL AID IN UNDERSTANDING SOURCE-SINK DYNAMICS IN GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS AND HOW CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES TARGETED TO BENEFIT ONE OR A FEW SPECIES INFLUENCES OTHER GRASSLAND SONGBIRDS. THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL ENABLE US TO DELIVER MORE STRATEGIC CONSERVATION THROUGH THE UWFWS AND PARTNERS AND HELP STABILIZE OR REVERSE POPULATION DECLINES TO THE BENEFIT OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE. THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA WILL BE THE SUB-RECIPIENT.

GRASSLANDS ARE A BIOME IN COLLAPSE. GRASSLAND BIRDS HAVE LOST NEARLY 50% OF THEIR POPULATIONS OVER THE LAST FIVE DECADES, YET WE STILL DO NOT KNOW THE CAUSES OF DECLINE. CONSERVATION FOR THESE GRASSLAND BIRDS REMAINS CHALLENGING BECAUSE THEY UTILIZE GRASSLANDS FROM THE GREAT PLAINS THROUGH THE CHIHUAHUAN DESERT AS THEY MIGRATE ACROSS THEIR ANNUAL CYCLE. AS SUCH, NEEDED ARE APPROACHES THAT CAN HELP SCIENTISTS QUANTIFY THE HABITAT REQUIREMENTS OF THESE DECLINING SPECIES ACROSS SPACE AND TIME. THE MOTUS WILDLIFE TRACKING SYSTEM (MOTUS), IS A RAPIDLY GROWING NETWORK THAT COMBINES AUTOMATED STATIONS AND SMALL RADIO TAGS THAT CAN DETECT ANIMALS AS THEY MOVE ACROSS THE LANDSCAPE. USFWS IS PARTNERING WITH BIRD CONSERVANCY OF THE ROCKIES TO DEVELOP THE MOTUS NETWORK ACROSS THE GREAT PLAINS AND CHIHUAHUAN DESERT TO FILL KEY KNOWLEDGE GAPS ABOUT HOW GRASSLAND BIRDS USE THE LANDSCAPE AND TO IDENTIFY WHERE CONSERVATION OF HABITAT WILL BE MOST EFFECTIVE. THIS PROPOSAL GROWS CATALYTIC SUPPORT TO FUND THE INSTALLATION OF SEVEN MOTUS STATIONS ON USFWS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES IN SOUTH DAKOTA, NEBRASKA, KANSAS, AND NEW MEXICO. THESE RESOURCES WILL GREATLY ENHANCE SPATIAL COVERAGE OF MOTUS TO INCREASE THE DETECTIONS OF GRASSLAND BIRDS THAT USFWS AND PARTNERS WILL BE TAGGING IN 2022 AND 2023. VIEWED CUMULATIVELY, THE EXPANSION OF THE MOTUS NETWORK ACROSS THE GEOGRAPHY WILL FACILITATE RESEARCH AND FILL KEY KNOWLEDGE GAPS ON THE MOVEMENT ECOLOGY AND DEMOGRAPHY OF DECLINING GRASSLAND BIRD SPECIES.

SINCE THE 1990S, THE GLOBAL POPULATION OF SALTMARSH SPARROWS HAS DECLINED BY ABOUT 75%, AND CURRENT PROJECTIONS SUGGEST THE SPECIES WILL GO EXTINCT MIN-CENTURY. IT IS WELL KNOWN THAT THE SPECIES REQUIRES HIGH-ELEVATION COASTAL MARSH WITH INFREQUENT TIDAL FLOODING TO ENSURE SUCCESSFUL REPRODUCTION. RELIABLE INDICATORS OF EXACTLY WHERE NESTS WILL BE SAFEST, HOWEVER, ARE LACKING. CONSEQUENTLY, IT IS HARD TO DETERMINE WHICH MARSH AREAS SHOULD BE THE HIGHEST PRIORITY FOR CONSERVATION, OR TO SET TARGET CONDITIONS FOR MARSH RESTORATION PROJECTS. SINCE 2010, THE SALTMARSH HABITAT AND AVIAN RESEARCH PROGRAM (SHARP) HAS COLLECTED DETAILED DATA ON THE NEST SITE CHARACTERISTICS AND FATES OF HUNDREDS OF SALTMARSH SPARROW NESTS DISTRIBUTED ACROSS >20 SITES THROUGHOUT THE SPECIES RANGE. WE WILL USE THESE NEST LOCATION AND FATE DATA TO BUILD AND TEST STATISTICAL MODELS THAT LINK REMOTE SENSING DATA WITH THE LOCATIONS OF NEST SITES AND SUCCESSFUL REPRODUCTION IN THE SEARCH FOR RELIABLE SIGNATURES OF HIGH-QUALITY NESTING HABITAT. WE WILL THEN USE SHARP'S EXTENSIVE DATASET OF GROUND-BASED SURVEYS THROUGHOUT THE NORTHEASTERN USA TO DETERMINE WHETHER SPECIFIC VEGETATION CHARACTERISTICS ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SITES THAT HAVE THESE SIGNATURES. USING THESE RESULTS, WE WILL (A) IDENTIFY SITES THAT ARE MOST LIKELY TO SUPPORT SUCCESSFUL SALTMARSH SPARROW NESTING, (B) DETERMINE WHETHER THERE ARE EASILY MEASURED VEGETATION CHARACTERISTICS THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SUCCESSFUL NESTING AND THAT COULD BE USED TO ASSESS RESTORATION SUCCESS, AND (C) EVALUATE THE POTENTIAL FOR USING REMOTE SENSING TO TRACK RESTORATION SITES AND REDUCE THE COST OF LONG-TERM MONITORING.

THE E.B. FORSYTHE NWR IS THE MOST IMPORTANT BREEDING SITE IN NEW JERSEY FOR THE FEDERAL AND STATE-LISTED PIPING PLOVER, AS WELL AS HAVING REGIONAL IMPORTANCE FOR THE RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES. IT ALSO PROVIDES ESSENTIAL HABITAT FOR OTHER AT-RISK BEACH NESTING BIRDS. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO TO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION, POPULATION, BREEDING SUCCESS, AND CAUSES OF NEST AND BROOD LOSS OF BEACH NESTING BIRDS AT FORSYTHE, PRIMARILY PIPING PLOVER, BUT ALSO LEAST TERN, COMMON TERN, BLACK SKIMMER, AND AMERICAN OYSTERCATCHER DURING THE ENTIRE BREEDING SEASON FROM APRIL 1- AUGUST 31. IN ADDITION, VARIOUS MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES, INCLUDING THE DEPLOYMENT OF PREDATOR EXCLOSURES, WILL BE IMPLEMENTED TO INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD OF NESTING SUCCESS. DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AND CATALOGUED CONSISTENT WITH ESTABLISHED FEDERAL AND STATE PROTOCOLS TO HELP TRACK SPECIES RECOVERY. PUBLIC OUTREACH WILL BE PROVIDED TO ADDRESS RISKS TO THE SPECIES AND EMPHASIZE THE IMPORTANCE OF REFUGE LANDS IN THEIR CONSERVATION.

THE MOURNING DOVE NATIONAL STRATEGIC HARVEST MANAGEMENT PLAN WAS APPROVED IN 2003 AND ADVOCATED FOR A MORE RIGOROUS, INFORMED HARVEST MANAGEMENT 
SYSTEM BASED ON POPULATION MODELS AND ADDITIONAL MONITORING PROGRAMS. IN 1999 THE HARVEST INFORMATION PROGRAM WAS INITIATED TO ESTIMATE
THE ANNUAL HARVEST OF MIGRATORY GAMEBIRDS. BY 2008 AN OPERATIONAL BANDING PROGRAM HAD BEEN ESTABLISHED IN ALL 43 HUNTING STATES THAT PROVIDES DATA ON ANNUAL SURVIVAL AND HARVEST RATES. A PARTS
COLLECTION SURVEY FOR DOVES WAS FORMALLY ESTABLISHED BY THE FWS IN 2007 AND PROVIDES DATA TO ESTIMATE ANNUAL PRODUCTIVITY. WITHOUT RELIABLE APPROACHES FOR UNDERSTANDING CHANGES IN ABUNDANCE, HARVEST
MANAGERS CANNOT ADEQUATELY ASSESS THE PROBLEMS AFFLICTING WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND PRESCRIBE APPROPRIATE ACTIONS. THE INTEGRATED POPULATION MODELING
(IPM) FRAMEWORK CAN BE USED TO JOINTLY UTILIZE LONG'TERM DATA OBTAINED FROM INSTITUTIONAL MONITORING PROGRAMS, AS WELL AS SHORTER'TERM DATA FROM
FOCUSED FIELD STUDIES THEREFORE IDEAL FOR EMPIRICALLY ESTIMATING EFFECTS OF HARVEST'MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ON POPULATION DYNAMICS, REDUCING 
UNCERTAINTY, AND GUIDING MOURNING DOVE HARVEST MANAGEMENT. THIS PROJECT PROPOSED TO COMBINE AVAILABLE DATA INTO AN UPDATABLE IPM FOR GUIDING THE 
MOURNING DOVE HARVEST MANAGEMENT AND INCLUDES FEATURES IN THE MODEL THAT CAN BE TRANSFERRED DIRECTLY INTO A QUANTITATIVE HARVEST MANAGEMENT DECISION PROCESS. THE PROPOSED IPM WILL ANALYZE AND EXAMINE
POSSIBLE EFFECTS OF POPULATION DENSITY AND HARVEST PARAMETERS (SEASON LENGTHS, BAG LIMIT, HARVEST RATES, TOTAL ANNUAL HARVEST) ON AGE'SPECIFIC 
SURVIVAL, AND THE POSSIBLE EFFECTS OF POPULATION DENSITY ON FECUNDITY.

CLAPPER AND KING RAILS ARE CLOSELY RELATED SPECIES AND HYBRIDIZE WHERE THEY CO-OCCUR.   BOTH SPECIES HAVE SHOWN RECENT AND SIGNIFICANT POPULATION
DECLINES AND BOTH ARE AT RISK FROM LAND USE CHANGE, MARSH LOSS, AND, WHERE THEY CO-OCCUR, SEA LEVEL RISE EFFECTS ON COASTAL MARSHES. THIS PROJECT
WILL CAPTURE AND TAG RAILS TO ESTIMATE HOME RANGE, MOVEMENTS, AND SURVIVAL, AND LOCATED NESTS IN DELAWARE. A SUBSET OF RAILS WILL ALSO BE MONITORED 
DURING THE NON-BREEDING AND MIGRATION PERIODS AND DATA WILL BE COUPLED WITH NEST SURVIVAL AND SURVEY DATA IN AN INTEGRATED POPULATION MODEL (IPM)
TO GENERATE A PRECISE ESTIMATE OF THE DELAWARE POPULATION OF CLAPPER RAILS.  THE PROPOSED GENETIC SAMPLING WILL ESTIMATE POPULATION CONNECTIVITY FOR
CLAPPER RAIL ACROSS THEIR U.S. RANGE TO TEST THE VALIDITY OF RECOGNIZED SUBSPECIES, AND THE GEOGRAPHIC RANGE FOR THE MIGRATORY VS THE NON-MIGRATORY
POPULATIONS.  ADDITIONALLY, TWO POPULATIONS OF KING RAILS WILL BE SAMPLED TO DETERMINE IF THERE IS EVIDENCE OF KING RAIL INTROGRESSION IN CLAPPER 
RAIL POPULATIONS. THESE SAMPLES WILL BE USED BOTH TO ASSESS POPULATION STRUCTURE AND GENE FLOW BETWEEN THE POPULATIONS AND TO ESTIMATE EFFECTIVE 
POPULATION SIZE USING GENOMIC TECHNIQUES.  UNDERSTANDING POPULATION CONNECTIVITY CAN PROVIDE VALUABLE INFORMATION FOR EFFECTIVE SPECIES MANAGEMENT 
AND OUR GENETIC ANALYSIS WILL ADDRESS THIS INFORMATION NEED.  IF THERE IS CURRENT INTROGRESSION BETWEEN THE SPECIES, IT MAY ALTER POPULATION DYNAMICS.

AMERICAN WOODCOCK POPULATION INDICES HAVE DECLINED, RANGE-WIDE, OVER THE LAST HALF CENTURY IN BOTH THE CENTRAL AND EASTERN MANAGEMENT REGIONS. THE SINGING GROUND SURVEY IS THE MAIN
TOOL USED TO MONITOR AMERICAN WOODCOCK AND RELIES ON COUNTS ON THE BREEDING GROUND DURING THE SPRING. HOWEVER, EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION OF AMERICAN WOODCOCK, IN LIGHT OF THESE DECLINES, HAS BEEN HAMPERED
BY A LACK OF INFORMATION ABOUT WOODCOCK MIGRATION AND HOW TIMING OF MIGRATION MAY AFFECT COUNTS DURING THE SINGING GROUND SURVEY. THIS PROJECT COMBINES RECENT ADVANCES IN GPS TRACKING TECHNOLOGY
WITH A LARGE-SCALE COLLABORATIVE APPROACH TO ADDRESS THREE KEY AREAS WHERE IMPROVED KNOWLEDGE OF WOODCOCK MIGRATION CAN BETTER ADDRESS MANAGEMENT NEEDS. THE THREE OBJECTIVES OF THE STUDY ARE TO: 1)
QUANTIFY THE TIMING OF FALL AND SPRING MIGRATION AND ASSESS VARIATION IN MIGRATION TIMING ASSOCIATED WITH WOODCOCK BREEDING GEOGRAPHY (I.E. BREEDING AND WINTERING LATITUDE/LONGITUDE), 2) DELINEATE MIGRATION
ROUTES AND MIGRATORY CONNECTIVITY FOR WOODCOCK IN THE EASTERN REGION AND EVALUATE CROSS-REGIONAL EXCHANGE BETWEEN THE EASTERN AND CENTRAL REGIONS, AND 3) EVALUATE RESOURCE SELECTION DURING
MIGRATION, INCLUDING THE LARGE-SCALE FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH SELECTION OF MIGRATORY ROUTES AND LOCAL FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH STOPOVER SITE SELECTION. ELEVEN STATES AND 2 CANADIAN PROVINCES WILL PARTICIPATE.
AMERICAN WOODCOCK WILL BE CAPTURED IN THE FALL AND WINTER AND TRACKED USING GPS TECHNOLOGY. RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY CAN INFORM HARVEST AND MIGRATORY HABITAT MANAGEMENT, AND HELP IMPROVE THE EFFICACY OF
THE SINGING GROUND SURVEY.
